div.p: Established 1726.

All communications for him should be addressed to Pension Wales, Sharia-el-Manakh.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Beautiful weather prevailed yesterday until 8 p.m., when there were vivid flashes of lightning in the N.W. and every appearance of an approaching storm. At 8.45 p.m. the weather became squally, with a moderate gale from the N.W. and a rising sea. A heavy shower of rain fell accompanied by heavy peals of thunder and vivid lightning. About midnight there was a flat calm and lightning was seen to the N.E. At 3 a.m. the weather became squally again from the N.W., blowing a moderate gale at times. There was a rough sea, vivid lightning, and frequent heavy showers, the total rainfall being 0.06. The barometer remained steady throughout.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
N.B.– Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. SNELLING.
Price One Plastre Tariff.
WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1904.

div.head: REDUCTION OF THE GARRISON.
div.p: The correspondence which has been filling our cloumns of late on the subject of the reduction of the Army of Occupation is interesting as being in a certain sense a criterion of that somewhat elusive social phenomenon, English public opinion in Egypt. None of the letters, which have appeared from the malcontents, have induced us to depart in the slightest degree from the opinions expressed in our leading article of Saturday week. The statements advanced by this section of our correspondents merit examination in order that the fallacies underlying them may be exposed. It is suggested by both "A Humble Imperialist" and "Old Officer," whose letters appeared in our issues of the 24th and 28th ulto. respectively, that those responsible for the reduction of the garrison are sacrificing military efficiency to electioneering tactics. This is, indeed, a grave allegation. Let us examine, then, the terms in which it is formulated and the grounds upon which it is based. "A Humble Imperialist" writes:– "The wrost thing for the Empire is an Imperial Defence Committee presided over by a party man like the Prime Minister, who would be tempted to put the exigencies of party finance before the true needs of the Empire." In the letter of "Old Soldier" the charge is reiterated with greater particularity. Economy, he tells us, is to-day a more alluring bait to dangle before the British tax-payer – and voter – than efficiency. "To reduce expenses by disbanding some regiments in Great Britain would not appeal much to the man in the street. But to increase the home garrison and at the same time decrease expense, is a valuable electioneering asset. For it mustbe borne in mind that any military unit is less in numbers and cheaper to maintain in England than abroad; en parenthese, it is also less efficient." We have quoted textually the words used by our correspondents in order that it may not be said that we have unfairly represented them. Both writers must be taken to know the facts upon which they evince in the controversy, it must likewise be assumed that they have perused the correspondence which had previously appeared in our columns. Now, we would take leave to inquire for what reason thses gentlemen have thought fir to gloss over a most important factor in this discussion, viz., that Egypt contributes to the maintenance of the British Army of Occupation. It was stated by "An Occasional Correspondent" in our issue of the 22nd ulto. that 84,000 is the annual contribution. We have been at pains to cinsult the estimates for 1904, and we find that the actual amount, as given in the "Stateman's Year Book," is L.E. 84,825. "An Occasional Correspondent," therefore, errs on the right side. It follows, then, as a necessary consequence, that by the withdrawal of 1,800 troops the burden upon the Egyptian Exchequer will be proportionatrly lightened, whilst that upon the British Exchequer will be, caeteris paribus, to an equal extent increased. Where, then is the economy which is to appeal so powerfully to the pockets of the British taxpayer – and voter? "Old Soldier" attempts to bolster up his contention thuswise. "It is cheaper," he says, "to maintain soldiers in England than abroad." Let him prove it. We will not dispute with him on that point because we are without the necessary knowledge, but after what he has written we are not prepared to accept his ipse dixit as conclusive. Let him substantiate, the actual saving to the British Treasury that will be effected by the reduction of the garrison. That is what he has to do to establish this branch of his argument. If he cannot do that, we would recommend him to be more careful in future over his facts before he attributes "unworthy" motives to any amn, least of all to the Government by which he is, or was, employed.

We further notice a minor error into which he has fallen but which, all the same, goes to emphasize his general unreliability. He refers to "some two and a half years ago, when the British barracks at Khartoum were finished, a British regiment was needed to garrison that salubrious spot. It was not found possible to spare one from Egypt and one was brought from outside, thus increasing the Army of Occupation by one regiment." Surely, "Old Officer," whose Imperialist solicitude is so over-mastering that he must needs give it vent by censuring in the public Press his present or former superiors, ought to be aware that the Suden is held jointly by the British and Egyptian Governments, and that, therefore, there can be no question of a British Army of Occupation in the sense that the term is understood in Egypt. The further point that both "A Humble Imperialist" and "Old Soldier" endeavour to make only tends to obscure the issue without advancing bu one iota their own contention. They ask us to believe without a title of evidence that this one was out-voted and that would launch us upon a sea of conflicting suppositions. And here we must enter our protest against such a method of canvassing official opinions from which one may happen to dissent. Nothing could be more mischievous than to attempt to impugn the decision of the authorities by the insidious suggestion, based admittedly upon pure surmise, that they were not in agreement, but that military counsels were over-ridden by party considerations. We prefer, and we trust that we shall carry the majority of our readers with us, to credit our Imperial Defence Committee with honourable intentions and patriotic conduct, rather than to suspect its members, without a shred of proof, of being traitorous political time servers.

The Standard announces that the Commissioner sent out by the Board of Trade to the North Sea, in order to examine the damage done to the trawlers which have not returned to port, has ascertained that twenty of them suffered from the Russian fire, some being seriously damaged.
There are a number of British cruisers lying in Arosa Bay (Spain).
The Admiralty announces that 14 ironclads, 13 cruisers, and a considerable number of destroyers are at Gibraltar.
(Reuter).
The Russian vessels retained here are the battleships Kniaz Souwaroff, Borodino, Orel, and Alexander III.
(Reuter.)
Three Russian destoryers from Tangier have arrived here.
(Reuter).
Lord Charles Beresford arrived here on board a destroyer yesterday, and had a long interview with the captain of H.M.S. Diana. (R.)
An unexpalined hitch has occurred. All the Russian fleet has now quitted the port, leaving behind four officers for purposes of the investigation.
(Reuter.)
Orders issued here point to the naval and military forces being held in readiness for all emergencies.
H.M.S. Casar to-day fired a gun recalling all officers to their ships. The latter have all cleared for action.
(Reuter.)
Count Benckendorff, the Russian Ambassador, had an audience with King to-day.
(Reuter.)
The Russian Squadron left in the morning.
(Havas.)
The garrison is confined to barracks; the British men-of-war are making patrols. (H.)
The rumour, accerding to which some difficulties have arisen in the settlemet of the Anglo-Russian incident, appears to be unfounded.
(Havas.)
To-day's proceedings at Gibraltar, which have caused a sensation in London and Eurpoe, partook largely, apparently, of the character of a demonstration.

Lord Lansdowne issued a statement to-night announcing that, before the Baltic fleet left Vigo, Russia undertook that it should not interfere with neutral commerce. Four officers were left in connection with the local enquiry. The two Governments are now discussing the terms regarding the international commision.
(Reuter.)
Four German steamers laden with coal for the Russians left for the Cameroons, and three British colliers for Reunion Island. (Reuter.)
Admiral Alexeieff leaves to-day fro Russia.
(Reuter.)
President Roosevelt has announced that the United States are negotiating an Arbitration Treaty with Great Britain.
(Reuter.)
A Dutch steamer sailed yesterday evening conveying Mr. Kruger's body to South Africa. The Dutch Royalties sent wreaths. (Reuter.)

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: MENA HOUSE HOTEL
div.p: opened yesterday.

div.head: THE WAKES ADMINISTRATION
div.p: will meet this afternoon under the presidency of Abdul Halim Pasha Assem.

div.head: STRAY DOGS
div.p: will be poisoned by the Cairo police on the night of the 3rd inst. in the Ghezireh quarter.

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL
div.p: will arrive at Alexandria by the train de luxe at 3 p.m. and will be distributed at the G.P.O. at 6 o'clock this evening.

div.head: MASSERINI'S MENAGERIE
div.p: is still drawing large crowds to the French Gardens. The latest attraction, feeding the serpents, is well worth seeing.

div.head: NEW DOCTORS.
div.p: – Mr. Charles Maxwell Ekins, Mohamed Ezzat, and Armeniops Boctor, doctors, have been permitted to exercise their profession in Egypt.

div.head: A FIRE
div.p: broke out yesterday morning in a house situated behind the Headquarters of the British Army at Cairo. The Fire Brigade extinguished the fire after 15 minutes' work.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE.
div.p: – The Popular Conservatoire of Music will give its second annual "epreuve" of the pupils in the hall of the New Khedivial Hotal on Thursday at 9.15 p.m.

div.head: THE SUBSCRIPTION
div.p: organised by the Editor of El Lewa in aid of the Turkish Fleet amounts up to the present to L.E. 109, M. 695. It is proposed to buy a torpedo-boat when a large enough sum has been collected.

div.head: FREEMASONRY.
div.p: – The inauguration of the new local Freemason lodge, "Germania, took place yesterday evening at the Masonic Hall, Alexandria, there being from 60 to 70 of the brethren present to give the lodge a "send-off."

div.head: THE HIRED TRANSPORT "DUNERA,"
div.p: sailing from Alexandria for home on 2nd December, will convey all details due for discharge, or transfer to Army Reserve, on completion of 4, 8, 12, and 21 years' service with the Colours up to, and including, 30th April next.

div.head: A GRUESOME DISCOVERY.
div.p: – A London paper states that on a bale of cotton, which arrived there recently from Alexandria, being opened, the corpse of an Arab, horribly crushed, was found inside. The unfortunate man had probably fallen in at the time the press was working and nobody had noticed the accident.

div.head: MURDERS
div.p: are reported from Manfalout and Farshout (Nag Hamadi). The cause of the Mansfalout murder appears to have been a goat, whose depredations in the murderer's field drove him into a violent fit of rage terminating in bloodshed. The fellah takes life on the very smallest provocation now-a-days. Was he ever law-abiding?

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: – On the 29th and 30th inst. 22 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these,, 16 were British, 3 German, 1 French, 1 Dutch, and 1 Italian. The transit and passenger dues for the two days amounted to 684,238.40 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 368 vessels amounted to 9,846,907.41 frs.

div.head: A BRAVE ACT.
div.p: – A few days ago, while the steam launch El Mounssef, belonging to the Quarantine Office at Suez, was alongside a steamer on duty, one of her steam valves suddenly exploded. A very serious accident was only prevented by the engineer, named Mazini, at the risk of his life, managing to stop the escape of steam. The man was badly burnt.

div.head: MURDER.
div.p: – The body found in the Rayah Teufiki at Dahadous village, Mit Ghamr district, proves to be that of a man named Taha Mohamed, an inhabitant of Bihada village, in the Kalioub district. A man named Bayoumi Amir, who was the last person known to have been in the company of the murdered man, has been arrested on suspicion. The inquiry is proceeding.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: – Plans for making certain alterations in the Khedivial Opera House in the interests of public safety were drawn up last winter by the Ministry of Public Works and are now being carried into effect Two boxes are being removed to make room for exits, one on each side of the parterre, leading to the stairways debouching at the entrance of the theatre.

div.head: NOTES FROM TANTAH.
BISHOP MORLEY'S VISIT.
div.p: Tantah, Tuesday.– Bishop Morley arrived here yesterday evening and held a service at 7.30 p.m. and this morning at 8.30 a.m. in the church-room. Both services were largely attended.

div.head: SCARCITY OF SILVER.
div.p: Although the cotton season here this year is very late and poor, our Moudirieh is already without silver. One wonders what it would have been if the season had turned out a good one. Since last spring I have been hearing of large consignments of silver arriving from England and Germany. Where has it all gone to? The Government should see that an ample supply is provided for the public'c requirements. I presume we shall soon see the "sarrafs" charging P.T. 2 or P.T. 3 for changing a soversign, as last year.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will leave Montazah Palace on Friday morning by special train for Dakilieh, on the Mariout line, to open the new mosque there. His highness will return in the afternoon to Montazah.
On Saturday morning his Highness will come down to Ras-el-Tin Palace.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: The following is the order of Saturday's reception at Ras-el-Tin Palace:–
At 9 a.m.– The Princes of the Khedivial Family, the Ulema, the heads of the State Administrations.
At 9.30 a.m.– The mixed magistracy, the native magistracy, officers of the army and navy from the rank of Bimbashi and upwards, and the civil officials.

At 10 a.m.– Unofficial military and civil personages having the rank of Lewa or Oula Sinf Sani and upwards; officers of the army and navy en disponibilite or retired having the rank of Miralai or Kamimakam; unofficial Keivil Beys, having the rank of Moutemaiz or Sanieh; the members of the Municipal Commission.
At 10.30 a.m.– The Diplomatic and Consular Corps.
At 10.45 a.m.– Field officers of the Army of Occupation; the clergy.
At 11 a.m.– Native and european notables and merchants.
The reception is reserved to residents of Alexandria.
The military will attend in undress uniform and civilians in frock-coats (redingote).

Civil officials admitted to this reception are those having at least the rank of sub-director or an equivalent rank, and those having at least the grade of Sanieh or Kaimakam, and magistrates appointed by decree.
The Khedivah will hold a reception at Ras-el-Tin Palace on the same day for the Princesses of the Khedivial Family and native ladies from 10 to 11.30 a.m., and for European ladies from 3 to 4 p.m.

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: (NOVEMBER 9.)
There will be the usual official reception at the Consulate during the forenoon.
In the afternoon the Consul-General and Mrs. Gould will be "at home" from 3.30 to 6.30.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, CAIRO.
div.p: The meeting of the All Saints' Church committee was held at H.B.M.'s Agency on Friday last, the Earl of Cromer in the chair.

There were present: Lord Edward Cecil, Sir William Garstin, Sir Elwin Palmer, Col. Colville, Capt. Lyons, Messrs. Elliot, Rowlatt, Hooker, Du Boulay, Alban, and Dean Butcher. The minutes of last meeting were confirmed. Mr. Hooker, hon. treasurer, presented the accounts, which showed that during the past year the offertories had increased, but the donations and subscriptions had not reached the usual amount.
Colonel Colville was elected on the committee in place of Col. Bullock, who had left Cairo.

Dean Butcher announced that the Rev. J. Thomson Burns, of Selwyn College, Cambridge (late curate at Enfield, Middlesex), was expected to arrive on October 30, to take the post of assistant chaplain. It was proposed that steps ahould be taken to get estimates for repair of church garden wall.
Thanks were voted to Mrs. Lyster and to Mrs. Charrington for gifts to the church.
The report of the Antoin Yusef Charity Fund was read by the president. Twenty-one cases had been relieved and 90 12s. 5d. expended.

div.head: MINISTRY OF THE INTERIOR.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has made the following modifications in its inspectorate:– Mr. Hornblower will inspect the Moudiriehs of Gharbieh and Behera; Major Elgood and Mohamed Suleiman, the Fayoum, Ghizeh, and Menoufieh; Mr. Monteith Smith, Assiout, Minieh, Ghirgheh, and Beni-Souef; Mr. Moberly, the Gouvernorat of Damietta and the Moudiriehs of Dakahlieh and Galioubieh; Mr. Hazel, Keneh and Assouan, and Harvey Pasha, the Moudirieh of Sharkieh.

div.head: MOTOR TRACTION FOR CAIRO.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes:– I notice in the Gazette of this evening an interesting paragraph on the subject of motor omnibuses for Cairo. I learn on very good authority that the Egyptian Government would be very pleased to entertain any proposition for such an innovation. The present progress of Cairo demands an efficient omnibus service. The Capital is increasing in all diractions. The traffic is enormous to what it was in recent years. The other day I counted 103 carriages crossing Kasr-el-Nil Bridge, returning from the promenade, in only seven minutes. From enquiries I have made I learn that this is a dailt occurrence. The introduction of motors both for omnibus and transport purposes would greatly alleviate the present pressure and also prevent much unnecessary cruelty to animals. There is no better managed society than the S.P.C.A. of Cairo, the infirmary of which I learn well repay a visit, but from what I learn the S.P.C.A. is powerless in the great majority of cases to effect any remedy owing to the Capitulations. I think a word of praise is due to the police for the admirable way in which they control the trafic in Cairo, including that of the motor cars, which in European cities are so difficult to deal with. Judging from this I should say that the introduction of motor omnibuses would in no way prove an additional source of ambarasment to the police or danger to the public.

div.head: NIAM-NIAM EXPEDITION.
OBJECT OF THE PATROL.
div.p: As very exaggerated reports have recently appeared in the British Press as to the proposed despatch of a patropl into the Southern Bahr-el-Ghazal, it is desirable that the correct facts should be made public.
This measure was decided upon a year ago, the object in view being the establishment of certain necessary Government posts and the further settlement of the country.
It is hoed that no resistance will be offered, but the patrol is strong enough to deal with any of the more turbulent chiefs, should they prove hostile.

The numbers and scope of the patrol are seriously misstated in the Press reports. The present is by no means the first patrol which has been despatched, such minor operations having been frequently undertaken in order to establish the Government, and rather to prevent the outbreak of hostilities by a timely display of strength than to provoke any collision with the local tribes.

div.head: MINING EXPEDITION.
div.p: Assouan, Wednesday.– Mr. J.C. Wells, Mining Inspector of the Finance Ministry, who left Cairo early in September on an important mining expedition, arrived at Assouan this morning, sunburnt, after having been sixty days in the desert and travelled fifteen hundred miles. He stays here for a day or two beofre proceeding to Cairo to report on the results of his expedition.

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: Constantinople, October 27.– The Cherit Avnul-Refik has signified to the Sublime Porte his opposition to the continuation of the railway to Mecca. At most he agrees to the line being prolonged to Medina. On the other hand, the line will not be extended beyond Maan in the meantime. From this last point a branch is to be constructed to join the Akaba Gulf. If this plan be carried out Turkey will possess an open door to Egypt. England is not likely to accept such a solution without reluctance, and will probably seek for compensation in Yemen or in the Hedjaz.

div.head: CHOLERA AND BERI-BERI ON STEAMER.
div.p: Last Sunday morning, when the S.S. Couledon arrived at Suez from Delaware Breakwater and Java, the Quarantine medical officer on duty, Dr. Vay, discovered amongst the crew two cases of Cholera and one case of beri-beri, all of which were landed in a boat and coneyed to Moses' Wells Hospital for treatment. The vessel, after being disinfected, entered the Canal in strict quarantine.

div.head: THE CRETAN MURDER.
div.p: At this morning's sitting of the Alexandria Native Tribunal, the man Menegakis, who is charged with the murder of a compatriot, Zakakis, near the General Post Office, was brought up for trial. Prisoner's counsel asked for the adjournment of the hearing to enable Menegakis to prove his Hellenic nationality. The case was therefore adjourned to the 17th December.

div.head: POLICE CHANGES.
div.p: Our Keneh Correspondent telegraphs that the Keneh and Minieh police commandants have exchanged posts.

div.head: CAIRO GAMBLING HELLS.
div.p: The farce of the police raid upon the gambling-dens that still exist within a stone's throw of Shepheard's Hotel is still continued almost nightly, and, naturally, with the same inevitable result of finding no gamblers nor gambling, for as soon as Captain quartier, the chief of the secret police service, accompanied by the kawass of the Hellenic Consulate, is seen approaching, his arrival is at once made known by the employes guarding the street doors through an electirc bell, and when he enters the gambling room nothing in the shape of a roulette wheel is to be seen.

Both we and our confreres in the Capital have, at different periods, called attention to this grave scandal, and it was hoped that when stringent instructions were sent from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs at Athens some months ago regarding this matter there would have been a change. Instead of this, however, we find that the largest of these gambling-dens, after remaining closed for a few weeks, has reopened its doors and is frequented nightly by its customary habitues.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE L'ELISIR D'MORE.
div.p: The first performance of L'Elisir d'Amore was given last night. The interpretation of the opers was very good, especially as regards the orchestra and the female choruses, some of the members of which possess very fresh voices. The tenor Zonghi sang well, more especially in the famous romance in the 3rd act. The baritone Badini and the comic bass Bordogni were excellent, while the light soprano at time distinguished herself. The opera did not attract a large audience; it is too old to please modern tastes. The music is spiritless, and the development of the piece is based on the conventional. The sweet and spirited melody which distinguished Donizetti's other operas is somewhat lacking here.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor sailed from Malta yesterday morning, and is due here on Friday afternoon, or possibly on Saturday morning, with passengers , mails, and general cargo.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Khios sails hence to-day direct for Liverpool with passengers and general cargo.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE.
div.p: "A Child of the Nile Valley" writes:–

Your leading article in the Gazette yesterday should be carefully considered by Lord Cromer and the official of the Public Works Department, besides the Free State Lands Department of the Finance Ministry. Egypt's greatest need at present is the creation of an Agricultural Department. At the present time the position of affairs is ridiculous. The Finance Ministry controls the Free State Lands Department, the Ministry of the Public Instruction is at the head of the School of Agriculture, the Veterinary Department is under the Sanitary Administration, Irrigation is subject to the Public Works Department, the Khedivial Agricultural Society is dependent on and regulated by the Finance Ministry, and thus the entire administrative direction of Egyptian agriculture is in a hopeless state of disorganisation owing to there being no real head. At the present time the Government is creating new official posts and is increasing the slalries of the more favoured officials, but there is no sign that any of the surplus funds now placed at the disposal of the authorities will be devoted to the creation of an Agricultural Department. If we want any agricultural statistics we have to go to the Alexandria General Produce Association's reports. Yet it would be quite easy to organise such a Department, for we have many excellent men who could be selected for the position of chief of the Department. Mr. Foster, the managing director of the Behera Company, would be an ideal man for the job. His great experience in the service of the Egyptian Government, and his achievements as director of the fortunes of the Behera Company, are sufficient qualifications. Again, there is Mr. Lang Anderson, the managing director of the Aboakir Company. His success as a most capable and energetic agriculturist is known throughout the length and breadth of Egypt. Mr. Foaden, the able secretary of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, would be a very suitable sub-director of the new Department, owing to his techincal knowledge. The newly-appointed chemist to the Agricultural Society, Mr. Hughes, and the entomologist, Mr. Willcocks, would be useful men on the staff. Mr. Monson would also have been a good man for the staff, but as he is devoting hinself to his own syndicate his services are not available. There are, however, other names, which I could suggest, but I do not wish to trespass at two great length on your valuable space. One of the first duties of such a Department would be to infuse new life into the School of Agriculture at Ghizeh, which is doing very little good at present time. The Veterinary Department is greatly handicapped at the present time owing to its connection with the Sanitary Administration. If placed under a Department of Agriculture its uses would be developed many times over. In fact, the capacity for good, which such a Department would possess, will be incalculable, and the sooner such an administration is created, the better it will be for Egypt.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: (Official communication).
La Delegation municipale s'est reunie le 1er novembre 1904 a 4 h. p.m. sous las presidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Presents MM. E. Benachi, P.Fenderl, Mansour Bey Youssef, Mohamed Bey Said, E. Stross, Soliman Bey Abani, G. Zervudachi, membres, W.P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky, secretaire.
La Delegation adopte les propositions de l'administrateur relatives a l'etablissement de classes pour le personnel de la Municipalite, question qui sera soumise a la Commission municipale.
Elle arrete les details relatifs a l'organisation d'un corps de police qui sera delegue par la police au service de la Municipalite.
La Delegation arrete les termes du reglement sur les chiens et la rage elabore par le service du contentieux d'accord avec les services sanitaires.

Elle examine les rapports et devis presentes par les services techniques et sanitaires au sujet de la construction d'une conduite d'eau filtree a Ramleh et ajourne sa decision, pour renseignements complementaires, a la prochaine séance.
La Delegation regle la question de l'administration du jardin Nouzha et decide de louer les parties non destinees au public a Moh. Attieh.
Elle charge le service du Contentieux d'elaborer un reglement pour les charrettes des marchands ambulants.
Elle prend note de diverses lettres du ministere del'Interieur approuvant certaines decisions prises par la Commission a la derniere séance.
La séance est levee a 8 jeures p.m.

div.head: COQUELIN AINE IN CAIRO.
div.p: Everyone who has ordered a subscription ticket for M. Coquelin Aine's series of performances at the Khedivial Opera House is requested to apply to the ticket and box-office for his tickets. Places, the tickets for which have not been applied for at the office before Saturday next, will be given to other applicants.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
First Class Hotel. Newly built. Sea breezes. Dry air. Near tramway station, the promenade, and Mustapha Pasha Barracks. Garden. Lawn Tennis. Good cuisine. Moderate charges. Open all the year round.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter. (Late of Thos. Cook & Son); also General Manager, Tewfik Palace Hotel.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. Rajrana Bhawani Singh of Jhalawar and suite, accompanied by Major R.A.E. Benn, Indian Army, are staying at the savoy Hotel, Port Said.
M. Maximoff, Russian Consul-General, arrived yesterday from Constantinople and left for Cairo.
M. Gennadis, Greek Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, will leave Cairo for Alexandria on Saturday next to receive the commander of the Greek Fleet on its arrival here.
Riaz Pasha left yesterday for Mehallet Roh, in order to inspect his estates there.
Mrs. M de C. Findlay, Mr. and Mrs. Verschoyle, Mr. and Mrs. Trevithick arrived in Cairo yesterday.
Mr. and Mts. E.W.P. Foster returned to Egypt yesterday.

The "at home" given in Mr. Alderson's Garden yesterday by Rev. Canon and Mrs. Ward, to meet Bishop Morley, was very successful. There was a large gathering, the weather was ideal, and the spot chosen a most happy one.
Sir Colin Scott-Moncrieff is coming out this season and will spend a month or two on the Nile. He will travel under the arrangements of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer Co.

The Hotel d'Angleterre, Cairo, will open its doors on the 15th inst. The manager has already received numerous orders for apartments. Among other inquiries we notice those of Lady Duffey and party, Col. and Mrs. Duckett, Mrs. Isabells Anderson, Misses Colins, Mr. and Mrs. Clapcott, Miss Scott, Miss Dresser, Miss Pigeon, Miss Walford, and Mr. and Mrs. L.H. Harokins, etc.
The visitors at the Grand Continental Hotel include Baron and Baroness Erlanger, Mr. Beauchamp Brown, and Professor Schilling of Bremen.
Mr. E.A. Harrison, general manager for Egypt of Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son, arrived at Shepheard's yesterday.
Dr. T.G. Wakeling, the resident physician at Mena-House, is returning by the Omrah, due to-morrow, Mrs. Wakeling will join him in a fortnight.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demi)

Le marche des valeurs, influence deja par les realisations de fin du mois, a subi ce matin un moment de panique a la reception des depeches. Bien que des telegrammes plus rassurants soient parvenus vers 10 heures, les cours cloturent cependant avec une baisse notable. Le meme mouvement s'est produit au Caire, nous telephone notre correspondant.
De 23 5/16 la Banque Nationale flechit a 23 1/16, l'Agricole de 10 15/16 a 10 13/16, la Daira de 21 9/16 a 21 7/16, la Nungovich de 8 15/16 a 8 7/8, et la Delta Light de 15 ½ a 15 5/16.

Par contre, la Salt & Soda hausse de 27/3 a 28/6 acheteurs avec tendance a la hausse et nombreuses transactions, les Dividendes Tramways de 365 a 367, les Eaux d'Alexandrie de 14 5/8 a 15 ½, et la Ramleh Railway de 8 7/16 a 8 ½.
Il regne une grande animation sur le marche et le nombre des affaires a ete considerable.

div.head: SUDAN IRRIGATION.
div.p: By Sir Hanbury Brown, K.C.M.G., late Inspector-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formely in Upper Egypt.
(Continued.)

If, in the future, a summer supply is obtained from storage reservois constructed on the Blue Nile or its affluents, the barrage and canals would serve to distribute it as efficiently as the winter water.
Concerning the river and land levels at the proposed barrage site, no information is given beyond the folowing:–

"The average height of the banls over summer water level is from 9 to 11 m. for the first 250 kiloms. upstream of Khartoum. Further south they rise and average over 10 to 12m. above low-water level. The difference in level between flood and summer is from 8 to 9m."

"A study of the (Khartoum) gauge registers shows that the highest range was 8.06 m. in 1869, and the lowest was 5.20 m. in 1877. Also that, as a rule, although this is not abosolute, the range of the Blue Nile in years of high flood is over 7 m., and of a low one below 6m. The range for 1903 was only 6.46 m., while for 1874 and 1878, both years of disastrous flood, the range at Khartoum was 7.20 m. and 7.51 m. respectively."

The water slope of the Blue Nile at Khartoum is given as 1/112000 in the flood season. As we are told that the banks rise higher above low water level as one goes south, we may assume that the natural ground slope 1/19000 or 10cm. per kilo. If the canals are given a water surface slope of 1/20000 the water level will be nearer country level by 5 cm. for every kilom. of distance from the head. If we assume 10m. as the height of the country above low water – the barrage site being within 250 kiloms. of Khartoum – and that the barrage holds up 6 m. head, the water surface in the head of the canal will be 4 m. below soil. As the water slope gains 5 cm. a kilom. over the country slope, the water will come to the surface in 80 kiloms. But by regulation, or by adpoting a flatter water surface slope, this length could be reduced to 50 kiloms. or 60 kiloms. Here we have the identical problem which faced Ismail Pasha's engineers, who were called upon to provide for the irrigation of the Khedive's sugar-cane estates in Middle Egypt alongside a chain of basins; a problem they solved without the help of a barrage on the river, as the existence of the corvee or unpaid labour system overcame the difficulty of want of ready money to pay for the large cubes of earthwork to be excavated. They dug the Ibrahimieh Canal with a head open to the river, and at Derut, 63 kiloms. from the head at Assiout, they constructed regulators to distribute the water between the basin feeders and the perenially flowing canals. The barrage and Ibrahimieh Canal head at Assiout, lately constructed, complete the scheme, which it is now suggested might serve as a model for a Blue Nile project.

Let us now consider how the proposed canals would work in flood. The rise of a mean flood is about 6 metres, and with such a rise and the barrage fully open, the same sonditions as regards levels would be produced as a low water when the barrage is holding up 6 m. If the natural flood fails to rise 6 m., it can easily be made to do so by regulating on the barrage, as it has been shown by actual practice that regulation during flood is safe. The Assiout barrage in the flood of 1902 held up 1.50 m., and the Delta Barrage held up still more.
(To be continued.)

div.head: THE STATE OF HELOUAN.
div.p: THE ROADS.

Owing to the complaints we have received from the residents at Helouan on the subject of the way that important health resort is neglected by the Public Works Department and the Sanitary Administration, a representative of the Gazette paid a visit to Helouan to see if these complaints were justified. The main grievances, it appears, are the water supply, the bad roads, the inefficiency of the local Municipal Commission, and the neglect of the Tanzim Department. The grievances are all justified and Helouan appears to have a good grounds for accusing the authorities of very great neglect.

There are only two roads outside the town, one leading to the Wady Hof and the other to the Nile. These are the only roads where visitors and the inhabitants can drive. The Nile road is very important, as it is the sole means of communication between Helouan and the Ghizeh province. This roas is in a deplorable condition. A few days ago the Tanzim Department made a slight effort to improve it. The sand of the roas, but whenever a strong eind comes it will all be blown back again on to the road. The road is lower than the surroungind desert and, consequently, becomes a receptacle for all the sand; whenever ther is any wind, the dust is carried on to the raod and makes it impassable.

The attempts of the Tanzim Department to temporarily improve the road by removing the sand to the sides are quite ineffectual, and merely lead to a waste of labour and money as the road is mot made any better by such expedients. The road ought to be thoroughly taken in the hand and the whole surface ahould be raised about three feet above the desert.

The surface of the road is full of holes, and the only system which the Tanzim Department pursues, is to put big stones into the holes, which makes driving and riding both dangerous and unpleasant. The strain on the horses is very great and the donkeys and mules, which take stones, etc., to the Nile, suffer greatly.

Two years ago, after several complaints had been made by some consuls in Cairo, whose subjects were interested in Helouan, the Tanzim Department spent about L.E. 1,000 for the purpose of repairing the worst parts of the track, which runs from the native village to-wards the river. The work was excellently done, but since then the road has been utterly abandoned. It is never watered nor swept and unless something is done soon, it will relapse into its former state. The expenditure of 24 per annum would have sufficed to keep tat part of the road in good condition. A sakkha with a ghirbeh could take the water from the canal running along the side of the road and water it daily at very little expense. As it is now, the Tanzom Department has wasted this 1,000 because it never took any pains, after it had spent the money, to see that the road was kept in decent order.
The Wady Hoff road, which is the only route to the hills, and affords a charming excursion for visitors, is equally neglected.

The Governement does not attempt to improve this state of affairs, and, whenever the Local Commission is approached, the only reply given is "Mafish felous." Of course, as the budget of the Commission consists of a miserable pittance of L.E. 1,500 per annum, not much can be expected, as the lighting of the town and the upkeep and watering of the roads, including all repairs, have to be undertaken out this amount. The Moudirieh of Ghizeh has not one-half of the superficies of roadway that Helouan has, yet the budget of that moudirieh for roads only is about ten times the budget of Helouan. As the local Commission can do nothing owing to poverty, the Governemnt ought to seriously take the question in hand and a grant ought to be given to the Tanzim Department for that purpose.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our corespondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit – within certain necessary limits – free discussion.

div.head: LADEIS ON STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,– This morning I saw a lady off by the 11.15 train to Mansourah. She had a second-class ticket. I asked the "farash" to find a ladies' compartment, which he did. It was occupied by two negresses, who had covered the seats with bundles of clothes, goulas, eggs, cheese, and other kinds of lumber. On applying to the proper person and pointing out that it was impossible for a European lady to travel with such dirty people, I was told there was no remedy, as this was the "Egyptian fashion."

Seeing the railway is run by Englishmen, this "Egyptian fashion" should be done away with. Surely a separate ladies' compartment for ladies travelling alone should be provided. There are many English ladies who cannot afford first-class fares, and it would be very easy to have a second-class compartment labelled "European ladies only." It also very often happens that women of very doubtful character travel in the second-class compartment reserved for ladies.
I am, etc., INDIGNANT.
Tantah, October 31.

div.head: HOUSEKEEPING IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,– I find housekeeping in Egypt most worrying and difficult, and I am sure I should not be the only grateful housewife, if you would publish in your valuable paper a list, monthly, of things that are to be in season, and the prices of them. I am almost certain my cook does not spend the money I give him, and that the prices he says he gives for the things are often double the actual cost. Not only this (which I don't mind if he provides enough for the different meals) but I get no change of food; the same thing day after day. For instance, I have had "French beans" as a second vegetable and "dates" for desert very much oftener than I care about.

When I remonstrate with him, he says there is nothing else in the "market," and as I do not know, and have no means of finding out, I cannot contradict him. I am sure if you would do this would be a boon to the English housekeeper in Egypt. Perhaps some of your readers would help you with the list, especially those who have lived out here a number of years, and are acquainted with the "dodges" of the native cook.
Yours, etc., A. HOUSEWIFE.
Cairo, October 1.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA FIRE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,– I am glad that you defended Super intendent Lynn from criticism of La Reforme. Like yourself, I watched the fire and was in dread of a great extension. I was amazed at the rapidity with which the fire, which was blazing out of several windows, was overcome. So pleased was I that, though a stranger to Mr. Lynn, I recognised by his accent in giving orders that he was a "Brither Scot" and could not refrain frompersonally congratulating him on his energy and skill.

If a visitor may be excused from gently offering a suggestion, it would be that simultaneous with the Brigade the police ought to arrive, as there was little attempt at controlling the crowd, and Mr. Lynn and staff were most unfairly handicapped in getting their hoses through the dense mass of people.

I noticed with interst and pleasure a gentleman, extremely well dressed, who, I learn, was a Mr. Barker of your city and who, amid the mud, sparks, and water, was very energetic, and by his means several hoses were playing a few minutes sooner than they otherwise would.
I am, etc., NORMAN HAMILTON,
Correspondent of London Daily Express.
Continental Hotel, Cairo, October 31.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL.
56th FIELD BATTERY ROYAL ARTILLERY
Versus
RAILWAY INSTITUTE, BOULAC.

This match was played on the Railway Institute ground on Boulac on Friday afternoon before an enthusiastic crowd of spectators. The Institute won the toss and McColl elected to play with the sun in his favour. The Artillery kicked off and the ball travelled towards the Artillery goal. Simmons centred to Cory and the Artillery were soon forced to give a corner. However, nothing resulted and the ball was sent again up the field, but Bell played finely and passing to Smith, that player shot at goal, missing by a very small margin. Gunner Topcott returned the ball into play, and after some neat footwork Smith centred to Cory, who beat Gunner Topcott, the Artillery custodian, scoring the only goal of the day. On play being resumed Bell gave a fine exhibition of back play. Wheeler Williams, ever ready to tackle his man, was baffled repeatedly. Hands was given against the Artillery when the home goal was in danger, the free kick saved the goal for a short time only. The Artillery backs played well and their forwards getting too eager, Referee Mr. J. Trotter blew his whistle for off-side. Esan was very soon in evidence. He kicked the ball neatly over his shoulder to Smith, and that player at once returned it to him after dodging Driver Campbell. Esan and Smith did some neat passing, and eventually Smith shot at goal, just going outside, the ball grazing the post. The artillery now were playing a strong hard game. Bombardier Sales, Gunner Mayhew, and Driver Campbell showed some fine combination work; they fed each other well, and but for Bell's good kicking and tackling, would have been very dangerous. Bell, getting the ball at his feet, ran well up the field and saved his forwards by a well placed kick, the ball going well into Artillery quarters. However, the Artillery men were not to be denied: they worked the ball back again, only to be foiled once more by McColl and Bell. The Artilery backs (Bombardier Pike and Wheeler Williams) played a sterling game and were ever on the ball. Gunner Topcott saved his charge from the shots which poured into his goal mouth until half-time. Half-time score: Institute 1, Artillery 0.

On resuming, play became fast and the ball sped away to the Artillery goal, where Hayes shot the ball over the bar, when standing in front of the Artillery goal. Esan was now seen to advantage; he forced a corner from Gunner Lungsden, but the back division cleared the Artillery goal, Bombardier Pike, S.O. Edwards and Gunner Lungsden combining to work the ball out of danger.McColl, getting possession of the leather, ran up the field and passes to Smith, who at once shot at goal, missing by a fractional part of an inch. The game now was very quick, Esan and Simmons shooting at goal in quick succession, but Gunner Topcott saved his charge every time. A shot from Cory nearly scored. The ball baing again in play, Bombardier Sales made a fine run, thus transferring the play to the Institute goal, where Appleby threw out the ball, which was taken up by Simmons, whi raced up the field and after a smart piece of passing, Smith forced a corner. The Artileery backs (Bombardier Pike and Wheeler Williams) again put in some fine work on front of goal. Gunner Price, getting possession of the ball, passed to Driver Cheeseman, who ran up the field and transferred to Gunner Barker, who shot at goal – but Appleby was not asleep. He kicked out and Hayes ran out the ball, passes it to Cory, who shot at goal, the ball striking one of the defenders. Hands was given against Donaldson and soon after a foul against Attswood, play being in the open when the whistle blew.
Final score: Institute 1 goal, Artillery 0.
GOLF.

At the annual meeting of the Kobe Golf Club lately, the annual challenge cup which is played for from scratch, was won by Mr. H.E. daunt with 80, comprised of 48 in the first round and 37 in the second round. This 9says the Kobe Chronicle) is the "Rokkosan record" in competitions for the round of 9 holes. The conditions of this competion are that all players starting for one event must compete for the others. Mr. Daunt is well-known in Cairo, where he spent last winter.

GENERAL AGENT OF THE ROYAL HUNGARIAN LOTTERY.
TELEGRPAHIC ADDRESS: "ELNASSIB." – TELEPHONE N. 1280.

The General Agency was created with the object of facilitating and rendering more agreeable the relations, and above all better protect the interests, of the numerous clients in egypt of the Royal Hungarian Lottery.
The Direction of the Lottery has already consigned to the General Agency the tickets of the XVth Lottery for public sale.
IMPORTANT NOTICE.– The drawings of the 1st class of the XVth Royal Hungarian Lottery will take place in the 24th and 25th November of this year at Budapest in the offices of the Direction of Lottery.

Please address all orders for tickets to the Banking Firm "El Nassib," General Agents of the Royal Hungariam Lottery, Alexandria, Rue Tewfik No.12. All information concerning the lottery is given free of charge, either verbally or by writing.
For the due execution of order, we respectfully ask our clients to let us have their orders by first mail accompanied by the remittance for tickets.
The drawings will be held publicly, in the presence of the Delegates of the State, of two Royal notaries, and of the Direction of the Lottery.

The absolutley protect the interests of the public the Hungarian Ministry of Finances has created a special Department charged with the mission of overseeing the movements of the Lottery. Moreover the HUNGARIN STATE guarantess the payemnt in the species of all the winning numbers.
The total value of distributed numbers during a lottery attains:
Crowns 14,459,000. Equal to Frs. 15,181,950. Equal to P.T. 60,727,800
The fortunate holder of the "GROS LOT" would win:
Crowns 1,000,000. Euqal to Frs. 1,050,000. Equal to P.T. 4,050,000

Immediately after the drawings, the official list of winning numbers, controlled by the Hungarian Government, are forwarded, even without demand, to the possessor of a ticket ot a fraction of a ticket.

As many clinets readily understand the combination of the ROYAL HUNGARIAN LOTTERY, and wish to be assured in advance that they will participate in "All th Drawings," the "General Agency" accepts all orders of total participation and guartees the entire execution without exacting the anticipated payemnt for all the drawings.
